title: Betrayal at Krondor
why: A surprisingly large and patient RPG from the early 90s, focused on writing, world-building, and consequence rather than spectacle. It trusts the player to read, think, and explore at their own pace, which feels rare even now.

title: Tir Na nÓg
why: A strange and ambitious early adventure game rooted in Celtic mythology. More about atmosphere and curiosity than mechanics, and impressive in how much it attempts on extremely limited hardware.

title: Not Tonight
why: A bleak but grounded narrative game that turns mundane systems like paperwork and queues into genuine sources of tension. It’s not subtle, but it’s deliberate, and it sticks with you longer than you expect.

title: Blitzkrieg
why: A slower, more methodical WWII RTS that prioritises positioning, preparation, and attrition over rapid micromanagement. Less flashy than its peers, but more considered.

title: Spelunky
why: A game that looks simple and then quietly punishes every assumption you make. Its influence on modern systemic design is obvious, but it still feels personal, harsh, and oddly fair.

title: Viva Piñata: Trouble in Paradise
why: A deceptively deep garden management game wrapped in bright colours and animal puns. Underneath the charm is a surprisingly complex web of systems that reward patience and observation.

title: The Outfit
why: A scrappy, destructive WWII action game that leaned into environmental chaos long before it was fashionable. Messy, uneven, but memorable in ways more polished games often aren’t.

title: Cel Damage
why: A loud, silly arcade combat racer with a strong visual identity and no interest in realism. It knew exactly what it was and didn’t apologise for it.
